title: This is how Newcastle United would have done this season with better injury luck
body_text:
This is how Newcastle United would have done this season with better injury luck
Any rational honest football fan would accept that this Newcastle United season has been affected by injuries.
So the debate is really about just how badly the missing players have affected the performances and results.
To put it another way, how has Eddie Howe performed in the circumstances AND how would he and Newcastle United have done, with less (or far less…) players unavailable?
This is how the Premier League table looks on Thursday (4 April 2024) morning:
As you can see, Newcastle United with 44 points in eighth place, 24 points off top spot, 15 points off top four, 13 points off fifth, four points off top six.
Compare that to how the top of the Premier League table looked after December’s first round of PL fixtures and all the teams having played 14 matches:
As you can see, Newcastle United had 26 points in sixth place, 7 points off top spot, 3 points off top four, 1 points off fifth.
So Newcastle picked up 26 points in their first 14 PL matches and then 18 in their next 16 PL games.
In the same time period as Newcastle have picked up those further 18 points, their rivals have picked up the following (number of games played ranges from 15-17 for these other clubs) – Arsenal 35 points, Man City 37, Liverpool 36, Villa 30, Tottenham 30, Man U 24.
In that first weekend of December, Newcastle United beat Man U 1-0, at the end of a week where with so many players missing, Eddie Howe had been forced to start the exact same 11 players (including 17 year old Lewis Miley all three games in a week, beating Chelsea 4-1 the previous weekend and that 1-1 away draw at PSG in the midweek.
The five matches that followed the 1-0 home win over Man U, were against Everton, Spurs, Fulham, Luton and Forest, to take NUFC to the 19 game point and having played every other team once. Nick Pope was injured at the end of that Man U match and United ended up with only three points from those next five games, which on paper was a generous schedule, with the fixture list having front loaded so many tough matches.
By the time Nick Pope got injured, it was the culmination of a horrendous period of over two months when the list of missing players had made things all but impossible. Pope’s injury clearly tipped us off the cliff and that has basically continued for another four months AND still continues. Eddie Howe missing at least an entire team of first team squad players for this Fulham match, as was the case against Everton on Tuesday.
So I want you to consider three scenarios.
Newcastle United averaging around 9 or 10 (or more!) missing players these past six months, averaging 6 or 7, averaging 3 or 4.
Newcastle United averaging 9 or 1o missing:
This is what the reality has been, absolutely unprecedented number of missing players, week after week, month after month. Newcastle United eighth in the table with 44 points.
Newcastle United averaging 6 or 7 missing:
I honestly think that with even 6 or 7 players regularly missing, which is beyond what pretty much any other rival club has experienced this season, Eddie Howe would still have had Newcastle United up around where Villa and Spurs are, so somewhere between fourth and sixth but definitely with similar number of points, around 56-59, not 44.
After all, despite having had a terrible situation with injuries in October and November, Eddie Howe still had NUFC after 14 games, just one point behind Spurs and three behind Villa.
Even if Newcastle had just kept up their points average per game from those opening 14 PL matches, it would have meant now NUFC on 56 points after 30 PL games.
Newcastle United averaging 3 or 4 missing:
This is kind of a normal situation, having three or four missing at any one time at the most.
If Eddie Howe had experienced this kind of normal luck, as he did the previous season when with a weaker squad than now, Newcastle United ended up fourth…
Well, in my opinion, Newcastle United would have been fourth as a minimum now. How close they would have got to bothering those top three… who knows?
The truth is though, that no honest person would say Eddie Howe and his squad have had ‘normal’ luck this season with players available. Which means you do have to also accept that it is unrealistic to think Newcastle United have gained anything like the number of points they would have done, if having just bad luck, never mind fair luck!
It isn’t a case of blaming every performance and every result (when Newcastle haven’t won) on the horrendous number of missing players this season. However, it is a case of saying that you have to accept that overall, the unprecedented number of unavailable players made it impossible to get close to where they would have been without that horrific luck.
Also worth pointing out, that in early December, Newcastle United were in the quarter-finals of the League Cup and facing the final Champions League group game. Even with having double figures of missing players, Eddie Howe’s side came within a couple of minutes of reaching a semi-final against Middlesbrough and also minutes away from reaching the last 16 of the Champions League (which they would have done anyway, if not cheated by that ridiculous penalty in Paris).
